title: Current-carrying wires - force in B-field at angle

content.question: A current-carrying wire is initially placed perpendicular to a magnetic field directed out of the page, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The wire is then rotated so that it is parallel to the field with the current directed into the page, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. Which of the following correctly describes the change to the magnetic force exerted on the wire from Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> to Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> and provides correct justification?

choices.label: The force decreases because the wire will not experience a force if the current is parallel to the field.
The force decreases because the magnetic field created by the wire in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> cancels the magnetic field around the wire.
The force increases because the wire will not experience a force if it is perpendicular to the field.
The force increases because the wire will experience a greater force with the current and field in opposite directions.

content.answer: The force decreases because the wire will not experience a force if the current is parallel to the field.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
